This type of concurrency problem can be a correctness issue, albeit with low probability. For instance, we could at any point read a not-fully-instantiated "_cachedColumnBuffers", which would not be null but still be in an invalid state, leading to a very tricky exception. This is a problem even without the byte buffer reuse -- use of the same InMemoryRelation in two different threads could now cause this issue.

@xwei-datageek @BaiGang The current naming scheme Problem+Algorithm doesn't scale. I'm working on some standardized interfaces so that we can decouple them. Do you mind me doing the review after that is done? Thanks!

I think there are major questions that will need to be answered before we could merge this PR:
- Is skew just a hint instead of a join type and how do we propagate that information through?
- @chenghao-intel asks a valid question about join keys.  I'm not sure how this could work without them.
- I think the current implementation of execute() is going to suffer from serious performance issues.  It does many passes over the data, does a lot of unnecessary string manipulation and computes several Cartesian products.  You will need to run some performance experiments with large datasets in order to show that this operator actually has benefits.

Actually, I think its worse if this is done for StateDStream, as in StateDStream the computation should be run even if there is no input data, as it is expected that the state update function is called on all the (key, state) pairs even if there is no new data. 

Regarding the fundamental reason behind doing this change, it seems that it is a nice-to-have from the UI point of view, and not really a system optimization. Regarding that, I dont have a strong reasoning against this but I have found that it is more confusing to have no jobs show up in the UI, as it is not even clear whether anything is running at all.
